Description: Small mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; well-modelled back, with accurately-shaped clypeus, double line for prothorax set well back, elytra drawn with single line, and triangle at junction with prothorax; at side, well-shaped legs, with projecting shelf underneath running round beetle; underside incised with clearly drawn representation of the 'Master of the Animals' who holds a lion upside down in each hand, whilst running to right; in greenish blue paste; rough and eroded surface; one extremity chipped.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The drawing of the lions and figure on the underside, combined with a very high standard of modelling of the scarab's body itself, finds some close parallels from Naukratis (such as Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 138-140, 147; BM 1886,0401.1687, BM 1886,0401.1688, BM 1886,0401.1689 and BM 1886,0401.1695). These examples display usually a Greek theme.

Hellenizing motif are popular on scarabs produced at Naukratis (on this production, see Webb forthcoming). The scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in Sardinia, south Italy, Carthage, Perachora and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 127-128, type XXXV, subtype 1-7, see especially 7 for this piece).
